title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" is the short title of this legislation. Congress finds that many students lack academic preparation in secondary school, leading to limited job prospects, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation in college. There is a consensus on the importance of raising academic standards and modeling them after advanced placement programs, which are endorsed by many education leaders and half of all states. The advanced placement program is offered in different college-level courses, reaching over 1,000,000 students, with test scores accepted at numerous colleges and universities worldwide. 24 States are funding programs to increase participation in advanced placement, including teacher professional development, mandatory course offerings, fee payment for tests, and public school requirements. The Advanced Placement program is offered in college-level courses to over 1,000,000 students, with test scores accepted at many colleges and universities globally. 24 States fund programs to boost participation in advanced placement, including teacher training, mandatory courses, test fee coverage, and public school mandates. 4 States require public universities to grant academic credit for scores of 3 or higher on AP tests, showing success in increasing enrollment, achievement, and minority participation. The Act aims to encourage more of the 600,000 students taking AP courses to also take the exams to demonstrate their achievements. The Act aims to encourage more students to take AP exams each year to demonstrate their achievements and build on the benefits of advanced placement programs, such as higher SAT scores and better grades. It also supports efforts to raise academic standards and increase participation in advanced placement programs. Additionally, the Act aims to increase the availability of schools offering advanced placement programs. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement programs for a more diverse group of students, including low-income and disadvantaged students. It also aims to provide access to advanced placement courses for secondary school juniors in schools that do not offer such programs, with the goal of increasing participation rates among juniors and seniors. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement programs for a more diverse group of students, including low-income and disadvantaged students. It aims to limit juniors and seniors in advanced placement courses to 25 percent of the secondary school student population and increase the number of students receiving advanced placement test scores for college credit. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for a 3-year period to carry out authorized activities. Eligible entities are defined as State or local educational agencies. Priority will be given to eligible entities applying for grants. Priority will be given to eligible entities demonstrating a need for advanced placement programs, involvement of business and community organizations, matching funds availability, focus on English, math, and science, and targeting schools with low-income students. An eligible entity may use grant funds to expand access for low-income individuals to advanced placement incentive programs, including teacher training, course development, curriculum coordination, books, supplies, and other related activities. The eligible entity can use grant funds to expand access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals. The entity must submit an application to the Secretary and report data on students taking advanced placement courses and tests. The Secretary will compile and report demographic information on individuals taking advanced placement courses and tests to Congress. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for on-line advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students without access to such courses. Grant funds can be used for various purposes. Grant funds provided under this section can be used to purchase online curriculum, train teachers, or buy course materials. Local educational agencies must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. Each institution of higher education receiving Federal funds must distribute information to secondary school counselors or advanced placement coordinators regarding academic credit for advanced placement test scores. They must also standardize the form and manner of disseminating this information within 4 years. Javits gifted and talented students will now have programs incorporating advanced placement courses and tests. The Upward Bound program will prioritize projects that increase secondary school student participation and success. The Eisenhower professional development prioritizes training in advanced placement instruction for grants and contracts under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The text discusses amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 related to providing professional development activities in advanced placement instruction and encouraging delivery of such instruction to underserved communities. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to provide education technology for advanced placement instruction and encourage delivery of such instruction to underserved communities. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to include the use of education technology for advanced placement instruction in underserved communities. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like "advanced placement incentive program" for providing activities to low-income individuals, "advanced placement test" administered by the College Board, and "high concentration of low-income students" for schools serving 40% or more students from families below the poverty level. The term "low-income individual" in the Act refers to someone who is academically prepared to take an advanced placement test, as determined by a school teacher or coordinator. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The terms "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" are defined in section 14101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The term "State" includes the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, and other territories.
